title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: Application: The first step is to submit an application, which usually includes a resume or CV and a cover letter. Some companies may also require candidates to complete an application form. Screening: Once the applications are received, the hiring team will review them to identify potential candidates who meet the basic requirements of the position. This may involve a quick evaluation of the resumes and cover letters to narrow down the pool of applicants. Initial Interview: The next stage is often a phone or video interview conducted by a recruiter or a member of the HR team. The purpose of this interview is to further assess the candidate's qualifications, experience, and fit for the role. It may involve questions about the candidate's background, skills, and motivations. Technical Assessment: Depending on the nature of the position, candidates may be asked to complete a technical assessment or task. This can involve coding tests, case studies, writing samples, or any other relevant exercise to evaluate the candidate's skills and knowledge. On-Site/Remote Interviews: Candidates who successfully pass the initial screening and technical assessment stages are usually invited for further interviews. These interviews can take place in-person at the company's office or remotely through video conferencing tools. The format may vary but often includes multiple rounds of interviews with different individuals or panels. a. Behavioral Interviews: These interviews focus on assessing the candidate's past behavior and how they handle various situations. Questions may revolve around teamwork, problem-solving, communication skills, and examples of accomplishments or challenges faced in previous roles. b. Technical Interviews: For technical roles, candidates can expect technical interviews to evaluate their expertise in specific areas. These interviews may involve solving technical problems, whiteboarding sessions, or discussing technical concepts and approaches. c. Managerial Interviews: In some cases, candidates may have interviews with managers or senior leaders to assess their fit within the organization's culture and values. These interviews may explore the candidate's leadership abilities, decision-making skills, and alignment with the company's vision. Reference Checks: Once the interviews are complete and the hiring team has identified their preferred candidate, they may reach out to the candidate's references to verify their qualifications, skills, and work history. This step helps confirm the candidate's suitability for the role and provides additional insights. Offer and Negotiation: If the candidate successfully clears all the interview stages and reference checks, the company may extend a job offer. This offer includes details such as compensation, benefits, start date, and any other relevant information. The candidate then has the opportunity to negotiate and discuss the terms before accepting the offer.
Interview Questions: Q: Walk me through your resume

Interview Questions: Career goals Questions about projects Why Stanford

title: Hospital Technician Interview

title: Undergraduate Intern Interview

Interview Descriptions: Multiple interviewers, straight forward interview with behavioral questions. Asked about experience, why I wanted to participate in this opportunity, what I would bring to the table. Interviewers were nice. Didn't seem like they had truly read my resume though. Ultimately, decided not to go through with the internship after many miscommunications, being left in the dark, and a lack of organization.

title: Patient Access Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Redwood City, CA) in Apr 2023
Interview Descriptions: I had conducted a group interview with access team and the manager got up and left during the interview and then came back into the virtual interview. Saying he didn't know about next steps on the role but had 5 people in the interview for over an hour. The manager asked off the mark odd questions. The lead representative called me in at 8am in the morning with no pre-text email heads up. They later cancelled the role 48-hours after I interviewed but then reposted it. Didn't respond to thank you notes. Huge waste of time, unprofessionalism, discrimination.
Interview Questions: What would you do if a doctor asked you to do something but its against policy.

title: Registered Nurse, BSN Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Apr 2023
Interview Descriptions: Initially had a phone call interview from the hiring manager, it was 20 mins and included patient scenario “who would you see first” type stuff. Had a zoom panel interview following the phone interview, which included 3 managers from different units. This interview was around 45 minutes, they asked me to walk them through my resume, we went through behavioral and patient scenarios, and I had to interpret cardiac rhythms. Overall interview process was great, I felt like they really made me comfortable during the process. It took exactly 26 days in total from the day I applied to the day I got offered.
Interview Questions: What do you like to do in your free time?

title: Registered Nurse, BSN Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Apr 2023
Interview Descriptions: Panel interview on a zoom call with 6 people (4 nurses, HR and unit manager). I was asked 6 behavioral questions and 3 clinical questions. Overall, interview took about 40 minutes.
Interview Questions: Behavioral: tell me about yourself, name a time when you didn’t know what to do, name a time you disagreed with authority, strengths & weaknesses, tell me about diversity, tell me how you deal with conflict from patients Clinical: stroke scenario, DM scenario and 3 patients, who do you see first?

title: Registered Nurse, BSN Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Apr 2023
Interview Descriptions:
I submitted my application for several positions through their Jobs website and waited for more than a week for a response. I had a phone call where I was informed that I did not meet the requirements for the position, as well as two Zoom interviews where it was determined that I did not have the necessary skills and experience, such as Epic charting and strong telemetry skills. 

Despite my efforts, I was not successful in securing any of the positions I applied for, which has been discouraging. There was one role where the hiring staff attempted to contact me multiple times over the course of three days, but unfortunately, I was occupied with other obligations at the time. By the time I was available to schedule an interview, the position had already been filled due to lack of response from me.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for Stanford Health Care? How do you want us to remember you? Why should Stanford Health Care hire you? Tell me about a time when you did not adhere to policy. ECG/EKG strip interpretation & management of the patient's condition, Prioritization of patients

title: Administrative Assistant II | Planning Design + Construction Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Mar 2023
Interview Descriptions: Disappointing experience overall to a once highly anticipated opportunity. Per the other interview experiences on here, the communication during the interview process was unnecessarily dragged out. I had to reach out the coordinating Executive Assistant several times to get an answer on who I would be interviewing with. When I finally interviewed, the team iterated how busy they were and needed this position filled asap. Meanwhile the soonest next step interview was two weeks out and I was sent the same blank invite, going in circles trying to find out who I would be interviewing with and never getting a response. Ultimately, I decided to withdraw. not what I expected coming from a place like Stanford.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your experience and how it correlates to this role?

title: Patient Financial Clearance Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Newark, CA) in Mar 2023
Interview Descriptions: The interview wasn’t stressful, nor were there difficult questions. I felt more so that she reviewed my work experience than explaining anything about the role. The interview seemed rushed, the hiring manager spoke over me not allowing me to completely answer her questions, and I could tell she had made up in her mind that she wouldn’t hire me based on me being in my current role for 6 months. On the initial screening call, she asked how much PTO I currently have remaining which was odd. I quickly noticed the red flags and asked that she withdraw my candidacy. I sensed this department has a high turnover rate and low employee morale.
Interview Questions: 1. How long does it take you to verify insurance in RTE? 2. Name two of your strengths and two weaknesses 3. If I were two reach out to your current or old employers, what would they say about you? 4. What has been one of your biggest challenges in working remotely? 5. Would you say you’re better working with insurance verification or prior authorizations?

title: Clinical Nurse II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Feb 2023
Interview Descriptions: K4 I did an interview over the phone and I felt like it went very well. She asked behavioral questions and about quality metrics and said I'd hear back next week. Next week comes, no word so I email them. No word again, so I email them again. I never got a response from them which really unprofessional of them. I get we're all busy, but it takes two minutes to send an email. Furthermore, I was sent a notice saying that the position was "cancelled" (instead of saying they've gone with someone else), which is a straight up lie because I know the person who got hired for that position over me. Do better.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had to reprioritize

title: Data Scientist Interview

Interview Descriptions: My first interview was with the hiring manager, who was was very personable and sincere. It wasn't a position for new grad, so it was very straight forward. We talked about my project experiences and my skills, she told me the expectations and wanted me to kind of "promise" that I wouldn't leave this position soon (several years) after I get this offer. I had no idea how to respond because I didn't know the benefits and the culture at all. A week later, the HR scheduled a call with me and told me all benefits. I decided to move forward but never got any response anymore. A month later, I was told by a systematic email that they hired someone else.

title: Staff Nurse (RN) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online, waited for about a week and got a call for a quick 15 min phone screen with the assistant nurse manager. Scheduled an in-person interview. Went in and had a panel interview with 3 nurses, all of whom were assistant managers. I was asked mostly behavioral questions, some clinical scenarios, and to interpret tele strips. Interview lasted about 30-40 mins. Got an email the same day to request for references. Was offered the position by HR (who texted me an offer, weird, I know) at the end of the day on a Friday. Accepted the offer and happy to be part of the team :)
Only issue was with HR, apparently she’s new but made a mistake in offering me a sign-on bonus when my dept is not eligible, sending me on-boarding docs last minute (the day they’re actually due), and having me send her my resume and getting an auto-reply that she’s on PTO -_-
Other than that, interview process with staff is great, they are responsive and quick to answer phone calls/emails
Interview Questions: What did you do to improve patient communication?

title: Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions: they did not conduct a phone screening. interviews consisted of two virtual panel interviews, one with the immediate team/colleagues/manager and another with the managers' colleagues. there were also a bunch of random calls and emails from the hiring manager. the manager said it would be a quick process but drew it out for weeks, stringing me along the way. while the Stanford name impressed me when applying, the team doing the interviews did not. the application/interview process is a two-way street and i didn't appreciate that this team didn't leave time to ask questions or bother to respond to them when e-mailed after the interview. all in all a poor experience.

In my opinion in the world we live in is not a fair way to evaluate.

title: Administrative Associate II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Jun 2021
Interview Descriptions: My position was for the Pathology Department. The process went smoothly in terms of the one-way interview and the three face-to-face interviews I did for the position. I was told that there would be a decision made after 2 weeks. The day after the interview, I was told that they would contact me the next day about reference checking. It never happened. After two weeks, I wrote an email about any updates and they said the hiring manager hasn't made a decision. I followed up after a month, and no response. I emailed again, but one of the other interviewers this time, and still no response. It's been more than 3 months now and I've accepted the fact that I have been ghosted. I wouldn't have been mad if they said they moved on with someone else, and I would've given the process a 5/5. Going from being friendly to ghosting makes it a negative experience.
Interview Questions: How do you prioritize handling multiple tasks and/or projects?

title: Laboratory Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions:
Pretty straightforward interview. The interview was with Becky (CLS) and Kenji (Operations manager) and was mostly questions on how I handle stress and how well I work with 
coworkers.  Other questions that were asked during the interview were just standard interview questions that you would be asked about at any other interview.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with stress from work?

title: Financial Counselor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Apr 2021
Interview Descriptions: I was set up with a zoom interview. Three people were to attend the interview, two of which were at least ten minutes late. This didn't feel like a professional interview but more like an interrogation. The request was for a zoom VIDEO call and two of the three interviewers never even turned their video on. One of the interviewers was just flat out rude. This was not a professional interview and Stanford Health Care should be aware of this.
Interview Questions: Many of the questions were not even clear/concise.

title: Digital Health Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online and initially received a generic rejection email. 

A month (?) later, received an email from the hiring manager to discuss my experience. This was a standard behavioral interview where I shared experiences and learned about their work. After this interview was a case study, and if that went well, an interview with the director.

The next step was a 'case study' where I was given a couple of questions to use for a slide deck. I had a week to prepare -- and they estimated that I should take like 4 hours to work on it. 

After this second interview, I never heard back from the hiring manager and got the same generic rejection email ~2 months later.

I probably would've preferred silence to the rejection email without any substance.
Interview Questions: Standard behavioral questions (tell me about yourself, talk about an experience when...., etc)

title: Project Management Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very comfortable and non-formal. For the most part it was like having a conversation and really trying to get to know me and me get to know the interviewees. Also a lot of explaining that regarding the culture of the organization
Interview Questions: What are your thoughts on Career Goals

title: Web Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions:
All video calls
15 minute screening call with hiring manager
1 hr panel interview (3 developers)
1 hr interview with hiring manager (conversation about departments’ suite of applications and opportunities for design improvement)

Initial contact about my application was unusual in that they just used a departmental email and signed off with the department name. I did not know who I was talking to until I was on the video call. In hindsight, I should have asked.

Panel interview was a good experience, fairly relaxed and conversational and no trick questions. We walked through a graphic design and a web project in my portfolio.

First and last interview with the hiring manager were a bad experience. They didn’t introduce themself and would not disclose their role in the department. In the initial call they asked repetitive questions. I interpreted this as I was misunderstanding the initial question, so I asked for clarification. But they didn’t not to provide any and just moved on. In the last interview, they asked unusual questions like “If another department offered you a job, would you leave this one for it?” and “Is your salary expectation higher or lower to your current salary?”.
Interview Questions: Tell me what you think the purpose of this job is and how your skills fit into it.

title: Clinical Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions:
Two part process. Phone and in person/video(since it was Covid times) 

Knowledge test at the end. Lots of good questions and scenario based. Know yourself really well and have scenarios ready for all sorts of questions
Interview Questions: How do you show compassion?

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions:
There were three rounds: 
1. R1; Behavioral - was with the team manager
2. R2; Data Presentation - was with the full team 
3. R3; Behavioral - was with the VP
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you used data to tell a story.

title: RN Traveler Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: Very quick interview. Interviewer was kind and understanding. The interviewer was interested with my skills and what I can contribute, also what I am looking for in a hospital facility. The interviewer made me feel comfortable and excited to start a new job there.
Interview Questions: Why I wanted to work there:

title: Nursing Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Stanford, CA) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very formal and traditional. They asked appropriate questions for my position and were very professional. It was pannel-style and included two staff nurses as well as the unit manager (who was also a nurse). I felt that it was a very appropriate process and very similar to other interviews for similar positions.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time that you had to deal with a difficult coworker and what do you do to overcome it?

title: Clinical Dietitian Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: Short phone interview w/ CNM, outlining daily jobs and responsibilities of RD + clinical nutrition questions related to pt care/daily prioritization/difficult pts + TF case study via email (reviewed by RD team)
Interview Questions: If multiple tasks that have the same deadline, how do you manage?

title: Graphic Design Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions:
It is nice.  At first three steps, it is responsive. It will need a design exercise. It takes 1 weeks. Then I go to interview.
 But it is not responsive in time at the final round. They should tell me whether I was accepted or not.
Interview Questions: Describe the your experience of design.

title: New Grad RN Residency Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: Zoom panel interview, with four questions per interviewee. There were the same questions for each person, so listen closely in the first round. Topic categories were teamwork, compassion, problem-solving, and patient advocacy. Also a introduction asking about you and why this institution is a good fit.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you had conflicting priorities.

title: Patient Admin Specialist II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Redwood City, CA) in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: Got an email a month after applying. Set up a phone interview. After a couple weeks got another email to set up a zoom interview with the team. Still waiting to hear back.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself, strengths and weaknesses

title: Medical Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Sept 2020
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview first . Then panel interview by team via zoom meeting. I was asked about 8-9 questions. Then I got offered on the same day and I accepted it.
Interview Questions: Tell me about the time you made a mistake and how did you correct it.

title: Clinical Nurse Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: first was the manage, second panel...waiting for the third round, I believe it will be with the doctors. I applied online and took weeks before someone gave me the first call for first screening.
Interview Questions: First screening was from the manager with few quick questions specifically  if your experience  fits the job. Second interview , panel about 4-6 I think..tell me about yourself, greatest weakness..mistake you've made, what can you bring to the table/job, communication style, how you manged a complex patient

title: Assistant Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: Stanford Healthcare posts all open positions on their website.  The request that a CV be submitted over the website.  If they are interested in speaking with you, they will contact you via email to set up a call, followed by Phone call, then in person interview.
Interview Questions: How do you manage and resolve conflict among team members.

title: Dietetic Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: Fairly typical interview process, which involved being interviewed by the supervisors and department head at the hospital. Once they decided to move forward with me, I was then connected to the contract company. I later was transitioned to be a direct-hire employee.
Interview Questions: Mostly asked about prior qualifications and experiences (e.g. school background, work experiences in food/customer service roles). Asked about how I managed conflict, to name my strengths and weaknesses, etc.

title: New Graduate Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions: Panel with 4 other candidates. They ask you 4 questions from 4 categories (EBP, QI, Compassionate Care, Teamwork). Each person gets a different question from the categories. The managers will reach out to you for a second interview if they feel like you are a good fit for their unit.
Interview Questions: Can you tell me about a time when you were unable to provide evidence-based care because of a patient’s beliefs? What did you do and what was the end result?

title: Clinician Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: This was a multi-step process. I had one phone screen with a recruiter, one phone screen with the department supervisor, one panel interview, and one additional interview with the medical director.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work for Stanford, and why this service?

title: New Grad Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Stanford, CA) in May 2020
Interview Descriptions: Applied online, received an email to interview Summer 2020. Interview was via  zoom. 4 applicants (including self), 7 unit directors, and HR rep to facilitate. HR rep asked everyone 5 questions.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself

title: EH&S Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Apr 2020
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process involved multiple phone screening interviews,  a panel interview, and a meeting with the actual hiring manager. A few days later I was asked to speak with the hiring manager's boss (Sr. Director). I was told I would hear back with their decision soon. Well, it has been months without a word. 

This lack of follow through and common decency to follow-up with someone who has gone through numerous interview rounds is definitely not what I expected from this organization. However, I was glad they showed me this side of their culture, which I want no part of.
Interview Questions: Why did I want to work at Standord HC?

title: Nurse Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: It was about one hour long. Interview questions were initially pretty standard. For example, "tell me about yourself." Progressed to scenarios such as "tell me about a time you worked with a difficult patient."
Interview Questions: They did ask about formula for ICP and if I have worked with specific drips

title: Accountant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was not very long. The online application was a simple process. There was a brief phone interview to determine basic information and brought in for an in person interview with the department.
Interview Questions: What makes you stand out as an applicant?

title: Physician Assistant Interview

title: Hematology/Oncology Fellow Interview

title: Patient Administrative Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Mar 2020
Interview Descriptions: Slow to get started, but overall similar to all other processes. I had two interviews, I could have easily had 3 interviews maybe even four if all upper management staff were available.

title: Social Work Interview Interview

Interview Descriptions: Interview was conducted by phone only in March due to COVID. Unpaid internship led to a very casual interview. Interview lasted about 20 minutes. Interviewer went into great depth about what the role entailed and what their expectations were of their intern.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to intern as a medical social worker?

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Jan 2020
Interview Descriptions: This consisted of a telephone interview followed by panel interview.  The telephone interview fairly easy; the panel interview intimidating because I couldn't "read" most of the panel.  Both interviews consisted of 100% behavioral questions, ugh.

title: RN New Grad Residency Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Jan 2020
Interview Descriptions: panel interview with nursing manager and 3 other students. Asked 4 behavioral questions, everyone took answer 1 of the behavioral questions until cycled through all question. Takes one hour long total.
Interview Questions: introduce yourself, behavior questions such as caring moment

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Stanford, CA) in Dec 2019
Interview Descriptions: Email screening and conversations. Two in-person interviews supposedly planned. I was only invited for the first one, which I attended and went very well. An HR person and the hiring manager interviewed me. Second planned interview was first delayed and then perhaps because of some internal policies etc. position was re-advertised. I was informed 2 months later about the interview outcome.
Interview Questions: Describe your past experience and how you are a fit to this role.

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Dec 2019
Interview Descriptions: I applied online on the Stanford hospital website. The nurse manager called me about a week later and asked behavioral questions over the phone - I went in the next week for the interview
Interview Questions: Tell us about yourself?

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Dec 2019
Interview Descriptions: Interview with manager and 2 assistant managers, was in person. Interview lasted about 45 minutes. Got an offer in the afternoon after the interview. There was no interview with HR.
Interview Questions: Previous experience and situational based scenario questions

title: Admitting Registrar Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Pleasanton, CA)
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online,  contacted by the hiring manager over the phone to schedule the interview, interview consisted of a panel of 3 mangers, interview flowed, hired on the spot
Applied online,  contacted by the hiring manager over the phone to schedule the interview, interview consisted of a panel of 3 mangers, interview flowed, hired on the spot
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Clinical Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA)
Interview Descriptions: Pleasant phone screen with Assistant Nurse Manager, received email for in-person panel interview. The in-person interview last for around 50 minutes. Be prepared to answer many behavioral questions. The managers are very nice with warm smiling. Due to 500P new hospital project, the whole hiring and interview process goes slow, took up to 2+ months. Since the new hospital will open in Fall 2019, there are still a lot of variables, be prepared to be flexible.
Interview Questions: Have you made any mistakes? How did you deal with it? What did you learn from it?

title: Advanced Practice Provider Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: I was invited to interview in-person for an APP role after two phone screens. I was not currently living in California when offered the interview.  When asked about possible reimbursement for travel, I was told Stanford does not reimburse for travel. Despite this, I decided to proceed with the interview because I believed it was a good opportunity. The day before my interview, I expected to receive an itinerary for the day; although I was in frequent contact with the interview coordinator, I never received an itinerary. First red flag. I was also not told about the format of the interview despite asking. As I entered the interview, the coordinator let me know that I would be asked clinical questions, which she 'had forgotten' to send to me the day before.  Another red flag. After the interview concluded, I was told that they would provide me with a decision in 1-2 weeks. 2 weeks passed and I had yet to hear anything.  I sent an email to the HR recruiter to follow-up; no response. I decided to log into the application website and saw that my application status had changed to 'No longer considered for the position.' The date of this status change was 1 week PRIOR to when I emailed the recruiter, and only a few days after my interview. I never received a formal rejection email or call, and had to find out via the website about my application status. I expected much MORE from an institution like Stanford, especially when I took the time to travel for the interview at my own expense. I believe that their interview process is extremely discourteous and uncouth. I will not recommend Stanford to any of my colleagues as a result.
Interview Questions: What is an issue that you foresaw potentially becoming a bigger issue and what did you do to prevent that?

title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: 1 week then phone interview after that panel with the hiring managers, im still waiting for the outcome of my interview.. still waiting gaming , not even received denial/rejection letter from the department I applied, they told me they will send email.
Interview Questions: Why Stanford

title: Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: Phone screen interview asking basic questions, why SHC then schedule for a video interview. Video interview were asking why this fellowship, name a time when you overcome a challenge? etc
Interview Questions: What are your strengths? What are your weaknesses?

title: LVN Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: Not as intimidating as I expected. The manager was nice and personable. I was made to feel at ease. Straight to the point questions.  Usually I'm nervous, causing me to stutter a bit but the interviewer had a calming demeanor.
Interview Questions: Expected compensation.

title: Nurse Practitioner Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Stanford Health Care
Interview Descriptions: Apply online. Once called it was a Two day interview process. Interviewed by a panel of people. Very intimidating. Need to be prepared before going in. Just relax and will do fine
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Manager of Advanced Practice Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Jun 2019
Interview Descriptions:
I was contacted by Stanford recruiter and had informative initial screening phone interview.  I then spoke with one of the managers in the recruiting department.  My information was then sent to the Executive Director of Advanced Practice.  She conducted a phone interview with me.  This was one of the most sterile, impersonal conversations I've ever had with a potential employer.  She sounded like she was reading off a list of questions, but not really actively listening to the answers.  After the phone interview, the executive director stated that she would be in touch.  

About two weeks later, I emailed her to check on my status.  Instead of contacting me directly, I was contacted by the initial recruiter.  The recruiter contacted me VIA TEXT MESSAGE to inform me that they were not continuing forward with me and were instead going with another candidate.  For any high level job, especially at the manager or director level, I expect more direct communication, not a casual text message. This was totally unprofessional and amateurish, in my opinion.
Interview Questions: Questions about dealing with challenging employees.

title: Clinic Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in Jun 2019
Interview Descriptions: Got a call for interview, met with assistant manager and coordinator of the clinic. I was going to come back for a second interview with the manager but she happen to be in office so I met her at the same time.
Interview Questions: How would you handle a difficult situation when you have multiple tasks at hand?

title: Diagnostic Medical Sonographer Interview
Application Type: The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care (Palo Alto, CA) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was great .  Be prepared to talk about your experience and how it relates to the job. Don’t be afraid to ask questions.  Be confident and ask good follow up questions
Interview Questions: Do you have any previous work experience

title: Relief Food Service Worker Interview

Interview Descriptions: Fairly straightforward. Asked about my work experience, customer service experience, availability, and food handling skills. Was interviewed by various people in the department I was applying for, most of them had a few specific questions.
Interview Questions: Why Stanford Health Care?

title: Nurse Practitioner Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Stanford Health Care in May 2019
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was prompted by an internal connection. I then spoke with an HR recruiter, she blatantly told me that the position would be difficult and the clinic has a high turnover, but the HR recruiter was very kind.  I also had an additional interview with the hiring NP. After this process neither of them reached out to follow up on the position. The lack of follow up after multiple interviews was extremely unprofessional. I reached out to inquire about the position and told they were looking for other, more experienced, candidates - I was lucky to find  and get hired to the same position at another major hospital.

title: Registered Nurse Interview

- Receive call back from hiring manager. Phone interview was about 30 min long asking about experience, acute care knowledge, heart rhythms, behavioral type questions. 
- Interview one week later. Interview was panel of 4 assistant managers. I went through my resume and they asked behavioral-type questions. They also set-up clinical questions for you to explain. Total was about one hour.
- Received email back two weeks later. Unfortunately did not get the position, but overall was a professional experience. Stanford has high expectations after all
Interview Questions: Was there a time you had a conflict with a doctor or clinical supervisor and how did you handle it

What interest you in stanford?
